In the last 10 years, I’ve used iPhones for 7 years, Windows Phone for 2, and Android for 1. Here’s my list: The notch. All of Apple’s current-generation iPhones have a large “notch” at the top, which was necessary to house the advanced Face ID infrared camera, but is unsightly and is not something that anybody actually wants. You’ve gotta figure that this will be resolved sooner rather than later, given how quickly other manufacturers have surpassed Apple in innovating around the problem. No expansion slot to add more storage. Apple would prefer if you pay them to get that storage upfront, even if you don’t need it right away, rather than risk the possibility that you’ll give your money to someone else. (They started doing this with Macs, too.) Limited dual SIM support. I think I’m correct in saying that Apple was the last phone manufacturer to offer dual SIM support. Probably because they had such limited sales in countries like India, Kenya, Indonesia and Bangladesh (that’s almost 2 billion people right there) where dual SIM usage is above 80%… they didn’t seem to understand the importance of this. Limited NFC support. Again, only the newest iPhones fully support NFC, making them several years behind the Android competition. And while the hardware is there, The Verge described the software experience as “a wonky workaround”. I’m sure this will get better, but it shouldn’t be as bad as it is. No fingerprint sensor on new phones. Face ID is really good, but being able to unlock a phone without looking at it is a very useful feature that is no longer available. Meanwhile, the competition is doing clever things like building the fingerprint sensor into the screen, or putting it on one of the side buttons…. Lightning port. The iPhone is the only phone that uses the Lightning port, which means you have to carry an iPhone-specific charging cable. Shoddy cables. Apple’s Lightning cables don’t last anywhere near as long as the phones do, so you’re probably going to be replacing it. I know I go through 3 cables per iPhone. Anyone recall having this problem with their old cellphones? No? Didn’t think so….  Headphone jack. Newer iPhones do not have a headphone jack, ostensibly for space-saving & water-proofing considerations, but more likely because they knew they were getting into the premium wireless earphone market and knew it would help sales. iPhones only run iOS. This sounds really obvious, but it does mean that you can’t enjoy any kind of software freedom with the $1,000 device you just bought. You wouldn’t accept this restriction from a similarly-priced computer, right? If you don’t like iOS, you can’t switch to Android or whatever. Can’t organize home screen how you like. Look, I really like many elements of iOS, it’s been very good to me over the years…. but the inability to lay out my home screen the way one would like, using a combination of widgets, application icons, and empty space…. it’s fucking barbaric. They even brought this nonsense to macOS in the form of “Mission Control”…. instead of doing the thing they should have done, which is bring the Mac’s ability to customize layouts to the iPhone. They’re slippery. Cult of Mac’s article “10 things I hate about iPhone X” puts it like this: “Its curved glass panels, coupled with its size and weight, mean it’s nearly impossible to go a week without dropping the iPhone X. And if you don’t drop it, it will surely slide off something or slip out of your pocket.” Battery is non-swappable. Before the iPhone, all the Blackberry and Palm road-warriors out there carried multiple batteries with them, often with a charger unit like this:  Battery running row? Just swap batteries and keep going! But Apple made it okay for manufacturers to making non-replaceable batteries, and it’s us, the customers, that have to suffer for it. Any browser you like, so long as it’s Safari. Apple has blocked Mozilla, Microsoft and Opera from offering their own web browser technology on the iPhone. Firefox and Edge for iOS are merely wrappers around Safari. This means you’re always using third-place browser technology, as demonstrated by this chart from caniuse.com:  iOS App Store anticompetitive behaviour: The US Supreme Court recently declared that an anti-trust lawsuit against Apple may proceed due to anticompetitive, price-gouging practices in the Apple App Store. (WIRED coverage: Supreme Court Deals Blow to Apple in Antitrust Case) … issues about Apple’s behaviour in this area keep coming up, like the recent (unrelated) accusations of anticompetitive behavior related to parental control apps, as well as the EU choosing to formally investigate over Spotify’s antitrust complaint. And that’s just from the last two months. The specific disadvantage to call out here is that the App Store places significant restrictions on the conditions by which you’re able to do business with a software maker. Apple demands that they be the only middle-man, and they always demand a cut — not based on the cost of providing the download service, but based on the software maker’s asking price. It’s basically a sales tax: Regressive by nature, and disproportionately disadvantages people of limited financial means. We’re paying more than we ought to be because of this racket.
